tasks.task: Managing agricultural biodiversity to mitigate pest impacts.
subtasks: Identifying and classifying various attackers in cultivated plots (parasites, diseases, predators, competitors).
Understanding the potential and observed losses due to these attackers.
Recognizing the limitations and negative impacts of chemical pesticide use in modern agriculture.
Considering alternative methods to reduce attacker populations using ecological biodiversity.
Implementing push-pull systems to leverage plant diversity for pest control (attracting/repelling mechanisms).
Exploring the benefits of using allelopathic plants to suppress parasitic seeds or pests.
Evaluating the economic and environmental advantages of integrated pest management strategies.

tasks.task: Presenting the potential of alternative pest control methods.
subtasks: Highlighting the toxicological concerns associated with excessive pesticide use.
Discussing the emergence of eco-friendly approaches in agricultural practices (e.g., reduced pesticide usage goals).
Illustrating successful case studies of biologically-based pest control systems (e.g., push-pull systems for maize).
Emphasizing the role of research and development in creating sustainable pest management solutions.
